awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: How do predators spread disease? Tests of five ecological and eco-evolutionary mechanisms with disease in the plankton
awd_abstract_narration:
A practical goal of disease ecologists is to find ways to stop or slow the spread of infection from host to host. A popular idea is that predators control disease outbreaks by killing infected prey which are weaker and thereby easier to capture. However, this proposal warns that predators may sometimes spread disease in host populations. The researchers will use organisms living in lakes to test five ways in which predators could spread disease. These ideas are that predators: (1) while eating prey, physically spread parasites into prey habitat; (2) can increase food supply for prey, and more food can cause higher parasite production within infected hosts; (3) can shift the composition of prey populations towards certain ages and sizes that get infected more easily; (4) can kill other species that control disease; and (5) can cause genetic changes to prey populations, making them more susceptible to disease organisms. The project will focus on water fleas (the hosts), a deadly fungal parasite, and an insect predator to test these possibilities. The research uses these organisms as a model system: outbreaks of this fungus can be sampled in lakes, created in experiments within lakes and in the lab, and can be understood using mathematical models. These new ideas, once tested thoroughly in the lab and verified in nature, will help managers make prudent decisions on how to control disease outbreaks in wild and domestic animal populations. The project will train many students, and focus on engaging those in underrepresented groups.
 
This project integrates three approaches. First, it will invest in a survey of fungal epidemics in water flea hosts in 40 lakes. The data from this large survey will be used to generate complex statistical models that test the first four mechanisms (ideas) given above. Second, it uses controlled experiments. One experiment will test mechanisms (2)-(4) with factorial manipulation of predatory insects and "competitor-diluters" (other water flea species which eat parasite propagules). A second experiment will investigate details of mechanisms (1)-(3). A third experiment investigates a tradeoff among clonal genotypes of the host; genotypes which better escape predation are more vulnerable to parasites. The hypothesis is that predators will shift host populations, via rapid evolution, towards bigger epidemics via this tradeoff. Third, this project develops a new suite of parameterized, mathematical (dynamical) models, designed to evaluate each of the mechanisms separately and together.

por.por_cntn:
Many ecological factors influence when and where a disease will spread in a population. Research that investigates how these multiple factors interact to determine that spread is important in understanding which aspects apply to a variety of diseases and which aspects are only important in specific environments or with specific disease-causing agents. This research investigated the role that predators of the host population play in disease spread. In some cases, predators are known to reduce disease spread by removing infected individuals from the population. In others, predators can result in increased disease spread because they increase the contact rate between healthy hosts and the infective agent.

This research demonstrated that whether predators increase or decrease disease spread often depends on other environmental factors including the number of species in the food web, and the type and amount of resources available to the host population. This research also investigated how those ecological factors influence how likely it is for a particular host individual to be infected. Work performed with this grant led to the understanding of how a fungal parasite grows within its host, and under what conditions that host can resist infection. The work also documented how gene expression differed between healthy hosts and those that were fighting infection. This work was accomplished by combining a survey of natural populations, with laboratory work that experimentally tested multiple hypotheses, with mathematical models that can be used to predict future disease spread. At the start of the award period, there was not enough knowledge to allow the mathematical models to produce results that matched the patterns seen in nature. By the end of the award, the knowledge gained from the laboratory experiments and refinements of the model resulted in model predictions that matched the natural patterns.

This work provided training and employment for six graduate students, 24 undergraduate students, and one technician. Trainees learned how to design experiments, and collect and analyze data. They also presented those data in a variety of venues. This grant influenced the content of courses in both biology and mathematics. The results of this grant have also been included in workshops and summer camps sponsored by the Champaign Park District (IL) and staffed by the faculty and students involved in the project.

Six publications and one Ph.D. dissertation have been published from this work. Five additional manuscripts have been submitted for review. The work has also been presented at locations within the United States and Europe.
